dataset.title: The impact of permafrost thaw on ecosystem carbon balance: CiPEHR Project Phenology of Dominant Plant Species II - Berry Production

address.deliveryPoint: 220 Bartram Hall; Department of Biology; University of Florida
University of Florida Department of Botany 220 Bartram Hall

abstract.para: This drying and warming experiment addresses the following questions: 1) Does ecosystem drying, warming and permafrost thaw cause a net release or uptake of C from the ecosystem to the atmosphere?, 2) Does the decomposition of old C that comprises the bulk of the soil C pool influence ecosystem C loss? 3) How do drying and warmign affect plant communities and ecosystem properties? We are answering these questions using a combined warming and drying experiment (DryPEHR), which is situated with the Carbon in Permafrost Experimental Heating Research (CiPEHR) project and located in an upland tundra field site near Healy, Alaska in the foothills of the Alaska Range. Warming treatment here refers to growing season air temperature warming (~1C) using open top chambers (OTC) combined with soil 'warming' using snow fences during the snow covered months. Drying is achieve using an automated pumping system that lowers the water table in the dry plots. Soil warming began in 2008; OTCs and drying in 2011. This data set includes measured values of CO2 fluxes during the growing season.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: corrections
section.para: Department of Energy NICCR Program; Department of Energy Terrestrial Ecosystem Processes; National Science Foundation CAREER Program; National Parks Inventory and Monitoring Program; National Science Foundation Bonanza Creek LTER program; National Science Foundation Office of Polar Programs, Arctic Natural Sciences Program

section.title: Methods
section.para: Phenology of the dominant plant species was monitored througought the growing season. Plots were surveyed starting after snow-melt through mid-September to determine the day of year (DOY) on which bud burst, flowering and senescence occured. Once plants had flowered, flowers and berries were counted in the entire plot (1m2) for each species. Bud burst was monitored 31 May - 24 June, Flowering 4 June - 2 July, Berries 31 July and 16 August, Senescence 16 August - 17 September. The species observed were: Betula nana (bud, flower, senescence), Carex bigelowii (bud, senescence), Rubus chamaemorus (bud, flower, berry, senescence), Vaccinium Uliginosum (bud, flower, berry, sensecence), Vaccinium vitis-idaea (flower, berry) and Rhododendron subarcticum (flower). Onset of senescence in B. nana and V. uliginosum was defined as leaves turning red and compete senescence when all leaves had dropped; in C. bigelowii and R. chamaemorus onset of senescence was defined as yellowing leaves and complete senescene if all leaves were yellow. Flowers were either counted as inidividual flowers (R. chamaemorus), infloresence clusters (.B. nana, R. subarcticum) or number of flowering tillers (C. bigelowii). Each treatment had two pseudo-replicated subplots. If a phenological event was observed in at least one of these two subplots, that DOY was used to determine first occurence. For flowers and berries averages were calculated from the two subplots, hence it is possible to have observed 0.5 flowers or berries.

section.title: Sampling Frequency
section.para: 31 May - 17 September 2013. Data was collected every 3-7 days.

dataTable.entityDescription: Phenology of the dominant plant species was monitored througought the growing season. For flowers and berries averages were calculated from the two subplots, hence it is possible to have observed 0.5 flowers or berries.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Samples are collected in 3 blocks, each block contains 2 fences (1-2; 3-4; 5-6). Within a block each fence is a split plot, winter warmed on one side, ambient on the other. Fences within blocks are replicates of each other

textDomain.definition: Samples are collected in 3 blocks, each block contains 2 fences (1-2; 3-4; 5-6). Within a block each fence is a split plot, winter warmed on one side, ambient on the other. Fences within blocks are replicates of each other

attribute.attributeDefinition: Each fence contains 8 plots, 1-4 on the ambient side of the fence, 5-8 on the winter warmed side of the fence. Summer warming treatments are nested within winter warming treatments, plots 1, 3, 5, 7 have open top chambers to produce a summer warming effect.

textDomain.definition: Each fence contains 8 plots, 1-4 on the ambient side of the fence, 5-8 on the winter warmed side of the fence. Summer warming treatments are nested within winter warming treatments, plots 1, 3, 5, 7 have open top chambers to produce a summer warming effect.

attribute.attributeDefinition: species for which data was recorded

textDomain.definition: species for which data was recorded

attribute.attributeDefinition: W = winter warmed side; C= control/ambient side

textDomain.definition: W = winter warmed side; C= control/ambient side

attribute.attributeDefinition: S = summer or air warming; C=control

textDomain.definition: S = summer or air warming; C=control

attribute.attributeDefinition: treatment label - Air warming refers to presence of an open top chamber, Soil warming refers to the winter warmed plots in which increased snow cover produces elevated soil temperatures, Air & Soil warming refers to open top chamber and increased snow depth treatments, Ambient refers to no air or soil warming treatment.

textDomain.definition: treatment label - Air warming refers to presence of an open top chamber, Soil warming refers to the winter warmed plots in which increased snow cover produces elevated soil temperatures, Air & Soil warming refers to open top chamber and increased snow depth treatments, Ambient refers to no air or soil warming treatment.

attribute.attributeDefinition: max number of berries, adjusted for the biomass of that species in the plot
